title: 110_hr6404
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Girl Scouts USA Centennial Commemorative Coin Act". The Girl Scouts of the United States of America was founded in 1912 by Juliette Gordon Low with the help of Sir Robert Baden-Powell. Low organized the first 2 Girl Scout Troops in Savannah, Georgia and dedicated 15 years to building the organization. She drafted the Girl Scout laws and it became the largest voluntary association for women and girls in the United States. The Girl Scouts of the United States of America, founded in 1912 by Juliette Gordon Low, has over 3.7 million members in 236,000 troops across the US and territories. They are part of a global family of 10 million girls and adults in 145 countries. Over 50 million American women have enjoyed Girl Scouting during their childhood. The Girl Scouts of the United States of America will celebrate their 100th Anniversary on March 12, 2012, as they continue to inspire, challenge, and empower girls worldwide. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 silver coins in commemoration of the Girl Scouts of the USA centennial. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted for the Girl Scouts of the USA centennial will be emblematic of the organization. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year 2011, and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Girl Scouts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities. Only 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of the coins minted under this Act, preferably at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary may issue coins under this Act only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2011. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES.

Sales of coins under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges will be paid to the Girl Scouts of the United States of America for Centennial efforts, including preservation of Juliette Gordon Low's birthplace. The Comptroller General can audit the Girl Scouts' expenditures related to these payments.
